content.value: In this episode of WYS, we discussed the idea of decentralized marketplaces with Washington Sanchez. He shared his thoughts on the intersection of freedom of commerce and freedom of speech and other places censorship-resistant technology could apply.
Co-founder and CRO of OB1.io, and core developer for  OpenBazaar a decentralised marketplace where you can buy or sell anything for cryptocurrency.
"I think decentralization for decentralization's sake is a huge error."

episodes.episode: Is Your Money Worth Your Time?
episodes.name: Paul Puey

content.value: Paul Puey sat down with us to discuss the foundational benefits of cryptocurrency. In this episode, he shares his view on the good and bad of advancing disruptive technologies and flattening hierarchies.

Paul is a proud Electrical Engineering and Computer Science graduate of UC Berkeley with a wide range of technical skills from low-level 3D graphics systems engineering to development of custom web CMS systems, back before people knew what a CMS was. 

He held a lead engineering position with Nvidia and significantly contributed to the design of highly cross platform software architecture enabling code-reuse across multiple ASIC generations and across multiple operating systems. A stickler for proper architecture, he insists on projects being designed from the ground up for maintainability and scalability.
"A digital money, accessable by anyone, anywhere in the world is powerful and levels the playing field."

In this episode of WYS, Bill Barhydt shares his perspective on the financial industry with respects to cryptocurrency, government, and technology. Hear his hopeful outlook on the future of money and how crypto will fall into that.

William (Bill) Barhydt (born in New York City) is a serial entrepreneur and the Co-Founder and CEO of Abra, a new type of digital cash payments app and network enabling the transfer of cash between any two smartphones.
"Over history, every government backed asset has failed."

We had the chance sat down with the inventor of digital cash, David Chaum to discuss the history of payment systems and how that has enabled the fusion of messaging with payments. He shares his insights on solving the problems that are infringing on societies digital and personal sovereignty.

Widely recognized as the inventor of digital cash, David is currently leading the Elixxir project to provide scalable digital sovereignty. He is also known for other fundamental innovations in cryptography, including privacy technology and secure election systems. With a PhD in Computer Science from UC Berkeley, he taught at NYU Graduate School of Business and the University of California, led a number of breakthrough projects as well as founded the International Association for Cryptologic Research, the cryptography group at the Center for Mathematics and Computer Science in Amsterdam, DigiCash, the Voting Systems Institute, and the Perspectiva Fund.
"In retrospect... the phone companies were so powerful, it seemed incomprehensable that they would ever lose their grip."
